executiveDashboard.noImmediateActions: No critical actions pending at the moment.
executiveDashboard.runSecurityScan: Run a Security Scan to calculate
executiveDashboard.costEvolutionDesc: Total cost vs net cost after credits
executiveDashboard.estimatedValuesWarning: Estimated values. Some recommendations may be mutually exclusive.
executiveDashboard.noSecurityDataDesc: Run your first security scan to see your security posture and identify potential vulnerabilities.
executiveDashboard.noFinancialDataDesc: Cost data will appear once your cloud accounts start reporting usage.
executiveDashboard.insightsWillAppear: AI insights will appear as data is analyzed
executiveDashboard.trendAnalysisDesc: Cost and security trends over time
executiveDashboard.healthScoreTooltip: Score from 0-100 that evaluates your AWS infrastructure's overall health. Considers security (critical findings), compliance (CIS, LGPD, PCI-DSS frameworks), performance (uptime, latency), and costs (optimization, waste). Updated in real-time.
executiveDashboard.uptimeSLATooltip: Availability percentage of your monitored endpoints over the last 30 days. Recommended target: 99.9% (less than 43 minutes of downtime per month). Includes APIs, websites, and critical services.
executiveDashboard.mtdSpendTooltip: Month-to-Date accumulated spending compared to planned budget. Includes all AWS services: EC2, RDS, S3, Lambda, CloudFront, etc. Updated daily via Cost Explorer.
executiveDashboard.savingsPotentialTooltip: Estimated savings identified by RI/SP analysis, idle resources, oversized instances, old snapshots, unused elastic IPs, and other opportunities. Based on real data from the last 30 days.
executiveDashboard.activeAlertsTooltip: Active alerts requiring immediate attention. CRITICAL: issues affecting production (offline endpoints, critical security findings). HIGH: significant risks that should be resolved within 24h. MEDIUM: recommended improvements for optimization.
executiveDashboard.operationsCenterTooltipDesc: Monitors the health and availability of your endpoints and services.
executiveDashboard.operationsCenterTooltipNote: This data is organization-wide and does not filter by cloud account.
executiveDashboard.financialHealthTooltipDesc: Overview of your cloud spending and savings opportunities.
executiveDashboard.financialHealthTooltipNote: Data is updated daily via AWS Cost Explorer.
executiveDashboard.securityPostureTooltipDesc: Security analysis based on AWS best practices and compliance frameworks.
executiveDashboard.securityPostureTooltipNote: Run regular scans to keep your security posture up to date.

steps.title: Follow these steps in AWS Console:
steps.step1: Access IAM Console â†’ Users â†’ Create user
steps.step2: Name the user (e.g., 'evo-platform') and create without selecting access type
steps.step3: In 'Set permissions', select 'Attach policies directly' and attach the JSON policy below
steps.step4: Create user. Then, access the user â†’ Security credentials â†’ Create access key
steps.step5: Select 'Application running outside AWS' and copy the generated credentials (Access Key ID and Secret)

mlWaste.title: ML-Powered Waste Detection 3.0
mlWaste.description: Machine Learning analysis of resource utilization patterns
mlWaste.noAccountDesc: Please select an AWS account from the header to run ML waste detection analysis.
mlWaste.selectAccountHeader: Please select an AWS account from the header
mlWaste.aiPoweredAnalysis: AI-powered analysis with real CloudWatch usage patterns
mlWaste.scriptsExplanation1: 1. These are AWS CLI commands that can be run in your terminal or AWS CloudShell.
mlWaste.scriptsExplanation2: 2. Make sure you have AWS CLI configured with appropriate credentials and permissions.
mlWaste.scriptsExplanation3: 3. Review each command carefully before executing, especially those marked as "destructive".
mlWaste.scriptsExplanation4: 4. We recommend creating snapshots/backups before any destructive operations.
mlWaste.scriptWhereTerminal: Run this command in your terminal with AWS CLI configured, or in AWS CloudShell
mlWaste.scriptWhereDefault: Run this command in your terminal with AWS CLI configured
mlWaste.scriptWhatTerminate: This command will permanently terminate the resource. Make sure you have backups if needed.
mlWaste.scriptWhatStop: This command will stop the resource. You can restart it later if needed.
mlWaste.scriptWhatModify: This command will modify the resource configuration to optimize costs.
mlWaste.scriptWhatSnapshot: This command creates a backup snapshot before making changes. Recommended before any destructive action.
mlWaste.scriptWhatDelete: This command will permanently delete the resource. This action cannot be undone.
mlWaste.scriptWhatResize: This command will resize the resource to a smaller/optimized instance type.
mlWaste.scriptWhatDefault: This command will apply the recommended optimization.
mlWaste.runAnalysisToGet: Run an analysis to get AI-powered optimization recommendations based on real CloudWatch metrics.
mlWaste.trackAllAnalysis: Track all ML waste detection analysis runs
mlWaste.runFirstAnalysis: Run your first ML analysis to see execution history here.

waf.noWafsFoundDesc: We didn't find any WAF configured in your AWS account.
waf.allWafsMonitoredDesc: All WAFs in your account are already being monitored.
waf.howItWorks1: WAF logs are sent to CloudWatch Logs in your account
waf.howItWorks2: A subscription filter sends events to EVO in real-time
waf.howItWorks3: We detect attacks, campaigns and threats automatically
waf.step1: Create a WAF in the AWS console
waf.step2: Associate the WAF with your resources (CloudFront, ALB, API Gateway)
waf.step3: Come back here to enable monitoring
waf.req1: WAF must be associated with a resource (CloudFront, ALB, API Gateway)
waf.req2: WAF logging must be enabled for CloudWatch Logs
waf.req3: EVO IAM Role must have permission to access the logs
waf.setupSuccessDesc: WAF monitoring has been successfully configured
waf.diagnosticDesc: Check the status of monitoring configuration
waf.testSetupDesc: Run diagnostic to test each setup step without making changes
waf.testSetupDialogDesc: Step-by-step test of each setup operation
waf.testSetupFailedDesc: One or more steps failed. Fix the issues above before enabling monitoring.
waf.testSetupPassedDesc: Setup should work. Click "Enable Monitoring" to proceed.
waf.stackUpdateRequired: The IAM role in the customer AWS account is missing permissions required for WAF monitoring. The CloudFormation stack needs to be updated.
waf.stackUpdateInstructions: Go to AWS Console â†’ CloudFormation â†’ Select the EVO Platform stack â†’ Update â†’ Replace current template â†’ Use the URL above â†’ Next â†’ Submit.
waf.blockedRequestsDesc: Requests blocked by WAF rules in the last 24 hours
waf.noBlockedRequests: No blocked requests in the last 24 hours

aiAnalysis.title: Intelligent Traffic Analysis

aiAnalysis.clickToStart: Click the button above to run an intelligent analysis of WAF traffic from the last 24 hours using AI.
aiAnalysis.successDesc: The AI analysis was generated and saved successfully.
aiAnalysis.processingInBackgroundDesc: The AI analysis is being generated in the background. This may take 30-45 seconds. Click 'Update Analysis' to check the results.
aiAnalysis.aiPoweredDesc: We use Claude 3.5 Sonnet via AWS Bedrock for advanced traffic pattern analysis and real-time threat identification.
aiAnalysis.organizationWide: This analysis considers data from all AWS accounts in the organization. For account-specific analysis, run a new analysis with the selected account.

rulesEvaluator.title: WAF Rules Evaluation
rulesEvaluator.description: Intelligent analysis of WAF rules with military-grade security recommendations
rulesEvaluator.warningTitle: âš ï¸ WARNING: Changes to WAF Rules Are Critical
rulesEvaluator.warning1: ALWAYS test in COUNT mode before BLOCK
rulesEvaluator.warning2: NEVER apply changes directly to production
rulesEvaluator.warning3: ALWAYS have a documented rollback plan
rulesEvaluator.warning5: Misconfigured rules can block legitimate traffic
rulesEvaluator.clickToEvaluate: Click the button below to start a complete evaluation of WAF rules using AI with military-grade gold standard
rulesEvaluator.selectAccount: Select an AWS account in the header
rulesEvaluator.practice1: Always test changes in staging environment first
rulesEvaluator.practice2: Use COUNT mode for 24-48h before changing to BLOCK
rulesEvaluator.practice7: Use AWS WAF Managed Rules as baseline

azure.quickConnectDescription: Connect your Azure subscription to EVO Platform
azure.noCredentialsDescription: Add your first Azure subscription to get started.
azure.deleteCredentialConfirm: Are you sure you want to delete this Azure credential? This action cannot be undone.
azure.subscriptionNameHelp: A friendly name to identify this subscription (auto-filled by the script)
azure.portalSetupInfo: Follow these steps in the Azure Portal to create a Service Principal with the required permissions.
azure.cliSetupInfo: Use Azure CLI to create a Service Principal. Make sure you have Azure CLI installed and are logged in.
azure.manualEntryInfo: If you already have a Service Principal configured, enter the credentials directly.
azure.step1a: Go to Azure Portal > Azure Active Directory > App registrations
azure.step1d: Supported account types: "Accounts in this organizational directory only"
azure.step2a: In your app registration, go to "Certificates & secrets"
azure.step2e: Copy the secret value immediately (it won't be shown again)
azure.step3Info: Go to your Subscription > Access control (IAM) > Add role assignment
azure.step4Info: Collect the following values and enter them in the form:
azure.clientSecretLocation: The secret value you copied in step 2
azure.replaceAppId: Replace <APP_ID> with the appId from step 1
azure.enterCredentialsDescription: Provide your Azure Service Principal credentials to connect your subscription.
azure.securityScanningDesc: VMs, Storage, SQL, Key Vault, NSGs
azure.permissionsValidDescription: Your Azure credentials have all required permissions.
azure.missingPermissionsHint: Add these permissions to the Service Principal or user in Azure Portal â†’ Subscriptions â†’ Access Control (IAM) â†’ Add role assignment.
azure.subscriptionMismatchDesc: The Subscription ID "{{requested}}" saved in this credential was not found among the subscriptions accessible by this token. This is NOT a permission error â€” the subscription does not exist or does not belong to the authenticated tenant/account.
azure.noSubscriptionsAccessible: This token has no accessible subscriptions. The OAuth token may have expired or the user may not have access to any Azure subscription.
azure.refreshErrorMessage: Connection expired. Please reconnect your Azure account.
azure.disabledSubscriptionsNote: Disabled or warned subscriptions cannot be selected. Please enable them in Azure Portal first.

oauth.selectSubscriptions: Select the subscriptions you want to connect
oauth.noSubscriptions: No Azure subscriptions found for your account
oauth.selectAtLeastOne: Please select at least one subscription
oauth.consentRequired: Your Azure administrator needs to approve this app
oauth.invalidState: Session expired or invalid. Please try again.
oauth.missingVerifier: Missing security token. Please try again.

azure.automatedScriptDesc: Run a single script that configures everything automatically
azure.scriptFeatures: The script will: login to Azure, list your subscriptions, create the App Registration, Service Principal, Client Secret and assign all required permissions.
azure.connectAzureDesc: Connect your Azure subscription using the automated script.
azure.step1RunScriptDesc: Download and run the script on your machine. It will automatically create the Service Principal with all required permissions.
azure.step2FillFormDesc: Copy the values from the script output and paste them in the corresponding fields.
azure.scriptRequirements: Requires Azure CLI installed and logged in. The script will guide you through the login if needed.
azure.tenantIdHelp: Tenant ID from the script output. Also found in Azure Portal > Azure Active Directory > Overview.
azure.clientIdHelp: Client ID (Application ID) from the script output. Also found in Azure Portal > App Registrations > Your App > Overview.
azure.clientSecretHelp: Client Secret from the script output. Keep it safe â€” it cannot be viewed again.
azure.subscriptionIdHelp: Subscription ID from the script output. Also found in Azure Portal > Subscriptions > Your Subscription.
azure.permissionExplanation: The Service Principal (App Registration) needs to have the Reader role assigned on the subscription to access resources.
azure.step1: Go to Azure Portal â†’ Subscriptions â†’ Select your subscription
azure.step2: Click on "Access control (IAM)" in the left menu
azure.step4: Select the "Reader" role (or "Contributor" for full access)
azure.step5: Click "Next" and select "User, group, or service principal"
azure.step6: Search for your App Registration name and select it
azure.step8: Wait 1-2 minutes for permissions to propagate, then try again
azure.authExplanation: The credentials provided are invalid. Please verify:
azure.checkTenantId: Tenant ID matches your Azure AD directory
azure.checkClientId: Client ID matches your App Registration
azure.checkClientSecret: Client Secret is correct and not expired

cloud.awsPermissionsDescription: Some resources could not be accessed due to missing permissions. Configure permissions in AWS IAM.

Hello! I'm EVO Copilot AI ðŸ¤–

I can help with:

â€¢ Resource optimization

How can I help?
copilot.welcomeMessageFull:
Hello! I'm EVO Copilot AI, your intelligent AWS assistant. I can help you with:

â€¢ **Cost Analysis**: Identify savings opportunities
â€¢ **Security**: Assess risks and vulnerabilities
â€¢ **Optimization**: Suggest performance improvements
â€¢ **Compliance**: Verify best practices compliance

How can I help you today?
